notesStmt.note: Whitman likely wrote the building specifications on what is presented here as the last page of this notebook first, and then flipped the notebook over and wrote notes from the other direction. References to the San Francisco can be dated to sometime after January 1854. The cover of the notebook is labeled "Note Book Walt Whitman" in a hand that is not Whitman's. Selections from this notebook were used in the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass. See Edward Grier, Notebooks and Unpublished Prose Manuscripts (New York: New York University Press, 1984), 1:113–117.

work.p: The subject of agitation appears in the poem that would become "Myself and Mine": "Let others praise eminent men and hold up peace—I hold up agitation and conflict" (1860, p. 224).

The words "emptier of privies" from these lines are echoed in the poem that would be titled "Song of Myself": "To a drudge of the cottonfields or emptier of privies I lean" (1855, p. 45). These lines also match the following lines from the poem: "Long have you timidly waded, holding a plank by the shore, / Now I will you to be a bold swimmer, / To jump off in the midst of the sea, and rise again and nod to me and shout, and laughingly dash with your hair" (1855, p. 52).

Lines from this section appear, revised, in the poem that would become "Song of the Answerer": "He says indifferently and alike, How are you friend? to the President at his levee, / And he says Good day my brother, to Cudge that hoes in the sugarfield;" (1855, p. 86).

div2.p: The boat starts out from her ship, and finds a vast cake of ice reaching from one shore to the other. Five times she drives into it, and five times recoils and has to put back.—The sixth time she plunges far desperately on, the ice opens a crack as she advances, and so makes a chance for her just the very way she most wants to go.—
